lexUnit.name: simmer.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: be in a state of suppressed anger or excitement.

sentence.text: Tensions soon simmered beneath the impression of domestic harmony and marital bliss .
I was somewhere on the curve of prejudice ; aware of an anger I had not dealt with , simmering beneath the surface , showing itself in bad dreams and disgruntled waking .
There was a darkness in his eyes , anger simmering just beneath the surface .
She was still quietly simmering from her interview with Naylor Massingham last Monday .
Anger has been simmering in SDLP ranks since DUP leader Ian Paisley and Mr Campbell both criticised the party 's ` power-sharing " policy in the run-up to last week 's election .
The rage of the Iceni spread through the south-east , affecting first the Trinovantes who had been simmering in discontent for some years .
Abruptly , unexpectedly the anger simmering inside her reached boiling point .
Now , naked , simmering with annoyance , the deepening light gilding him , he was no less imposing .
Later , when she went to the dining-room , Lucy was still simmering with resentment , and she knew that unless she pulled herself together it would begin to show .
In fact , Diana 's indignation at Raine simmered for years until finally it boiled over in 1989 at the church rehearsal for her brother 's wedding to Victoria Lockwood , a successful model .
With so many confused emotions simmering away inside you , it 's difficult to know where to turn .
So she sipped champagne , and smiled , and ate , and all the while her fury against Naylor simmered away .
They may be quietly simmering over something they feel very strongly about .
Mahmoud was another one who did n't take a siesta and just at the moment , still simmering over the way Zoser had slipped through his fingers , he was driving his men hard .
With black hair , and moods to match , for I was more capricious , my blue-grey eyes mirrored the sullen nature and restlessness which ever simmered within .

Discontent simmered and a new element , political Radicalism , appeared in the shape of peripatetic agitators , critics like William Cobbett who spoke to crowded meetings on his ` rural rides " through Sussex in 1825 .
He looked totally at ease , prepared to wait forever , and Paige 's temper began to simmer .
